Fascinating and very heartfelt interview. There are very visible changes in his demeanor from the youthful and self-deprecating 'Normal One' to the more hardened version of himself that is often grumpy with journalists and certainly with referees. I think it demonstrates the relentless pressure that Premier League managers are under in a billion-pound business that is so closely scrutinised by media, statisticians, owners and fans alike. From a Bolton fan I can honestly say this man will be sorely missed, not just at Liverpool but all English football... I was worried Liverpool were in trouble until he arrived. They've always had the talent they just lost consistent leadership, especially after Gerrard hung his boots up, too. It seemed like there were too many holes to fill to rebuild on, but what he's done has been both entertaining and phenomenal. Something about the guy just makes everything seem fun again, like every decision could lead to an education or entertainment. He never made the fans carry the weight of his mood like many other prem managers do. Also the dedication and trust he inspires from him players is rare in the mainstay prem teams today. Yet he's built an inspirational team of not just the men on the pitch but also fans they can be proud to represent. As both always show inclusion and good sportsmanship, worthy of the team that's back to being the pinnacle of British football.  I genuinely hope Liverpool continue to build on and honour the legacy he's built and whoever you find to take over is up to the job.  ğŸ‘ğŸ¾ğŸ‘ğŸ¾ğŸ™ŒğŸ¾ YNWA ğŸ‘ğŸ¾ğŸ‘ğŸ¾ğŸ™ŒğŸ¾

Dear JÃ¼rgen, you did it. You managed to give us hope again. You managed to make us believe in something again.  You sacrificed your heart and soul to get this club back where it belongs. But you have created far more. You have created a feeling, an identity that is rarely seen in football today. It was felt that you were completely committed to this club with every cell in your body and that means more than any title that Manchester City has ever achieved or will achieve. You said it doesn't matter what people think about you when you come, but when you go. Well, you leave behind a legacy, an era full of great emotions, incredible comebacks and tragic final defeats, but above all, beautiful Anfield moments that couldn't have been more magical. You are the one who pushed our players to the extreme. You are the mentor who taught us to win again. You are the Savior who brought home the long-awaited championship for us. Thank you for being with us, we will miss you. Thank you JÃ¼rgen

As strong and long-life "Red" supporten... I can't discribe how much SAD & UNHAPPY I am, by listening this TITAN says to us "Goodbye"!!! But, I'm truly, really UNDERSTANDING Klopp the HUMAN! He's human, like all of us, he's not... "Robocop", he's not a cyborg to simply change an energy cartridge and to be "Ok" and go on. I know, because I found MYSELF in his place too many times, when I had to say "NO MORE, I HAD ENOUGH - I WANT TO LIVE MY LIFE, I CAN'T DO THIS ANYMORE, I WANT A BRAKE!"...  I can't figure out WHO would an equal replacement for this TITAN. It's not, actually, about his manager's skills. Hell, we can find someone with his skill, I'm sure. THE PROBLEM IS... how we will be able to find someone WITH HIS QUALITY AS MAN, AS CHARACTER? That's the super major problem! Klopp is not "JUST" a great football manager, he's a GREAT MAN! The bond he has with the club... the supporters... the players... the stuff... the ENTIRE CITY of Liverpool... that's so UNIQUE, so PURE, that I can't figure WHO ELSE can be THAT MUCH PERFECT "MATCH" for us!!!  I truly believe, the retirement of Klopp is EQUAL SO UNIQUE & SOCK like... Bill Shankly... or Bob Paisley... was back then in their era! Yes, I know, Liverpool had many GREAT managers... but to me, if I want to pick Liverpool's "Holy Triangle"... that's BILL, BOB & JUNGER, period!!!  Oh boy... At least... let's hope STEVIE G will be onboard, in next June! I would be A BIT less sad, when Klopp farewell us...

Herr Klopp, I have been a Liverpool supporter for almost 65 years, since I was the age of 5. I visited Anfield with my Dad who was in turn a massive supporter and although we lived in Dublin (Liverpool is a Parish) we went to many dozens of home games after travelling on the ferry from Dublin. When you arrived almost 9 years ago you said you wanted to make doubters into believers and that you would win a major trophy in 4 years! Well that 4 years turned into 5 minutes as the style and playing skills of the team blossomed under your coaching and I remember well how you turned despair into pride for me at least. I now live in Nelson, New Zealand and usually have to either get up at ungodly hours or stay awake to to support my team as best I can from here! It is no longer a chore but a joy to see how you have again revitalised the team since last year. You know, I cannot thank you enough for all the joy that you bring me! I am so very proud of what you have achieved on my behalf! If you are ever down this way you are welcome to share  my home! YNWA  Danke lieber Freund

I was shocked initially as we all were and now that i have been able to process it for a day it feels like i am in mourning.                 This man picked us up when we were in a pitiful state and took us all the way to champions of the world! I think about our final home game and his goodbye and I feel a lump in my throat and my eyes well up. I never even felt like this for greats like Gerrard, Carragher who called time at Liverpool after so many years. This is different. I used to think what will we do without Gerrard and here we are mostly because of Klopp.                             I dont know who we will get for next season but it will be tough to fill the boots of a manager like Klopp. It is rare when a clubs identity is so closely linked to its manager but Klopp achieved that. Its a tough one to take especially when he has won so much and knowing that he deserved to win even more and coming so close to doing so. He really deserved a league or 2 more and a champions league more at the least so I hope they can get over the line this year in the league which i know is going to be a tough ask but what a send off that would be. Grateful for the memories and for those to come in the next few months but at the same time I am heartbroken. These 9 seasons have really flown by and we should just enjoy the little time that we have left. What a ride it has been. YNWA

I'm a life long Man United fan.   Mr Klopp is a terrific manager, but more than this - a terrific person. He brought greatness back to Liverpool, and I don't just mean trophies. I mean class, honour, playing and living the right way. His teams echoed this on and off the field. I personally think that he should have taken a break rather than leave - but what I think on that is only one view, and not one that matters. While for much of his tenure, my club has been in the doldrums, but not for Liverpool FC.   And in his tenure, he found, enjoyed, embraced the people and the city - and they - him. His time, his experience - and that of the Liverpool fans will in the near future, role into a period of excellence, regeneration, victories, and fond memories. He will be a very hard act to follow.  As a bystander, or as simply a football fan - I have enjoyed the football played, in the right spirit and the words and deeds of the man in his time. He will be sadly missed and I wish it were not so. To the fans, salute the man down the stretch and give him a send of he deserves, and enjoy the moments. They will I am sure be special.   It will be our loss to not clash swords in the future with the man, and I acknowledge it fully. To the man, the club, the team and the city - best wishes for the future. I will miss you sir.
Jurgen Klopp's departure is bad news for the entire PL. He brings a warmth and humanity in stark contrast to the businessmen that are wringing the game for every penny and want to turn it into the football equivalent of the NFL. He's honest, charming, funny and relateable. There's images of him driving into work in an Opel Kadet! he will be missed that's for sure.

In 2018, a distant echo reached my ears from across the Atlantic, whispering of a team in red that transcended the boundaries of a sport. It wasn't just about goals or victories; it was about principles, fairness, and doing things right. Liverpool FC emerged, adorned with names like Salah, Milner, Henderson, Robertson, Mane, and Firmino â€“ a symphony of talents guided by the maestro himself, Jurgen Klopp.  Klopp isn't just a manager; he is an architect of dreams, weaving threads of energy, positivity, and belief into the very fabric of Liverpool. In the alleys of Anfield, a transformation unfolded â€“ not just of a team but of a city, a fan base, and a mindset. Each match was a brushstroke on a canvas, crafting a masterpiece of resilience and camaraderie.  And today, as Klopp announces his departure to us, I reflect on a journey that transcended the boundaries of football. His legacy isn't just the trophies, but the spirit, the fight, and the indomitable will to stand up for what's right. In every cheer from the Kop, in every chant echoing through the city, Klopp's impact reverberatesâ€”a testament to the enduring power of a team that plays not just with skill, but with heart.  As the final whistle approaches, I honor and celebrate the man who infused not just a game, but a way of life, with his artistry. Klopp, the conductor of dreams, will leave behind a symphony that will echo through the hallowed corridors of Anfield and beyond, inspiring generations to come.   You'll Never Walk Alone â™¥ï¸

Dear Jurgen,  I remember how tough for me was when Torres left. I remember how hard was to see Suarez go. It was heartbreaking when Gerrard left. Nothing less was when Mane, Hendo and Firmino left.  But it's nothing compared with this sad news, this one will be hard to swallow. I have always been behind you, trusted you on every step of the road, never questioned your decisions, listened to many press conferences where I learned some great lessons for which I am very grateful. You and the group rewarded us, fans, with memorable time, matches and trophies.  Had some rough times in the past, I was really struggling to get a grip and when almost everything around me was dark and bad, you and boys created for me (every sunday) a small space where everything was great and sunny,. This space was one of few reasons or my fuel to keep going forward.  I just wanted you to know how much you mean to me, and every other Liverpool fan. While you were doing your job the way you did, you made some "invisible" ripples which touched and inspired people all around globe, including myself,  to start doing and live with the same attitude, mentality and values. I don't know is there anything more important than that. I would say that neither trophy can match to that.  It is really hard to resist temptations of praying you to stay, and I will try not to do that.  I will, as always, stand  behind you, trust you with all my heart and try to enjoy and absorb as much as I can while it still lasts. And of course, cheer harder then ever! Thank you, from the bottom of my heart.  Sincerely, Alex. â¤

My dearest JÃ¼rgen Klopp,  As the news of your impending departure from Liverpool FC broke, a wave of disbelief and sadness washed over me. It felt like a punch to the gut, a swift and unexpected blow that left me reeling and struggling to comprehend the magnitude of this loss.  For years, you have been the heart and soul of our beloved club, the driving force behind our triumphs and the beacon of hope that illuminated our darkest moments. Your infectious energy, your unwavering belief in our players, and your unwavering determination to succeed have transformed Liverpool from a team in the shadows to a force to be reckoned with.  Under your guidance, we have witnessed the impossible become possible. We have tasted the sweet nectar of victory, celebrating Champions League glory and Premier League titles in the stands, our voices hoarse from cheering and our hearts overflowing with pride.  But now, as you prepare to embark on a new chapter, our hearts ache with the emptiness that your departure will leave. We feel like orphans, cast adrift without our guiding light, our unwavering supporter, our source of inspiration.  We beg you, JÃ¼rgen, please reconsider your decision. Stay with us, lead us further into glory, and continue to write the chapter of Liverpool FC's history that you have so masterfully crafted.  We need you, JÃ¼rgen. We need your passion, your vision, and your unwavering belief in the power of this club. We need you to guide us through the challenges that lie ahead and to help us achieve even greater heights.  We know that you have given your all, poured your heart and soul into this club, and that you have dedicated every fiber of your being to our success. But we also know that you have unfinished business here, that there are still dreams to be realized and trophies to be lifted.  So please, JÃ¼rgen, don't leave us now. Stay with us, lead us forward, and help us write the next chapter of Liverpool FC's remarkable story.  We are Liverpool, and we are with you.  With heartfelt sorrow,  A Devoted Liverpool Fan

Roberto De Zerbi is the only manager who can replace Klopp's kind of football, which shifted from quick transitions to progressive possession futbol with Fabhino & Firminho at the helm & now to a mixture of both styles with MacLister at the pivot. Klopp was all about tempo & intensity & as an Arsenal fan, i feared them more than city. I have never seen a team whose base is transition become so adept at possession, especially when Van Dijk signed. (Real possession, not Unai Emery measured kind) De Zerbi has also shifted from heavy possession to an an interpid mixture of quick transition with possession fundamentals. Futhermore, De Zerbi, with his Italian pedagocal base, can improve players technically in the same way Klopp was able to marry the athletic and aesthetic. Not surprised to see Llana and Milner shift to Brighton. The only other manager i can see is Unai Emery. Xabi Alonso is not the guy because his brand of futbol has more of a La Liga sensibility and tempo.    The main issue with Klopp is that his futbol was perfect for the Anfield crowd, an almost perfect marriage and it will be difficult to find that tempo of futbol ever again. He's quite singular, an august manager who futbol i will miss.

I am still stunned by this news - but waking up to this awful news this morning; I had to do a double take that it wasn't 1 April! However, thinking about this, tbh, at several of Jurgen's pre-match conferences this season, I've said quietly " Gosh he looks tired, drained - I do hope he is alright!" Because I do - all us LFC fans knew he would leave at some point; just please not now - well at the end of the season. Because we have so much promise in terms of what we can still achieve. I respect him too much to question his timing of this announcement - one of his best qualities is his honesty in my book. To delay things once his mind was made up so there could be leaks and speculation before an announcement - that would not have been who we respect - love even. I wish Jurgen and his family only the best in the future - he is an exceptional human being. Wherever and whenever I see him in the future - I believe I'll smile and know "Once he was OURS". All the very best Jurgen, thank you, thank you.

Wow, just wow...I'm not a Liverpool fan (although I often wish I had chosen them as my English team), but I am a huge Klopp fan and I thought that this was a marriage made in heaven, a perfect fit...I still think so, actually...  This is such a Klopp thing to do, pure integrity...a humble man who loves the game, clearly loves Liverpool...doing what he thinks is best for the club and himself...truly a class act...I really hope that most will respect his decision and the timing of this announcement and try to make the remainder of the season as brilliant as possible...that would be the proper way to part ways...  I have to admit that this does make me very sad....I love watching his teams play, especially his Liverpool teams...but, at the same time I am happy for him as he is doing it his way and is clearly getting on with his life as he chooses to....Good on him!  It's strange, while I do support another club I now want Liverpool to win everything they can this year as a fitting tribute to such a great manager and human being...that would be true poetry in a world that increasingly seems to lack grace.  Klopp knows that he will never walk alone.  (edit:  The EPL will never be quite the same again...a real loss for all who love the beautiful game and the best league in it)

Jurgen Klopp brought LFC back to the forefront after some very mediocre seasons and although this sad news will be hard to take for a lot of our supporters, we have to show this man our love and respect for his decision. Sometimes us fans don't realise how much of a mental toll it takes on a manager, a player, or anyone associated with this great game because we love football so much. ...this is like the old tale of the "keeper" in charge of a huge powerfull monster called "wisdom"; learnt by heart all the beast's whims and wishes, how he must approach and how touch him, when is dangerous and tame, and why; learns his language too--what sounds he usually makes at what, and what sounds uttered by another creature quiets him and what infuriates him.The keeper learn this lessons perfectly in the course of time by living with him, and calls it wisdom. He knows nothing in truth about these resolutions or whims of the multitude, wether any of them is beautiful or ugly, just or unjust, but gives a name to each according to the monster's opinion, calling beautiful what pleases the monster and evil what annoys him. There's no other principle in this, but calls necessities just and beautifull; and how really different by nature necessity is from good he has neer seeing it for himself and is unable to teach another... My point is, that is no easy with that much pressure at that level to impart good ruling... Klopp is the only Liverpool manager I've ever known.  As a Yank who started following EPL after watching the Hillsborough 30 for 30 in '14 and subsequently falling in love with the people of Liverpool and the team, I am heartbroken.  I played many sports as a kid, and I can say unreserverdly Klopp is the type of coach I could only dream of having.  A coach that believes in you and builds you up while also holding you accountable and being tough when necessary.   His connection and love for the fanbase is also remarkable.  The three fist pumps to the kop were always a highlight.    It will be strange and unnerving to watch another manager walk the touch line.  All that said no one person is bigger than the club.  YNWA is a not just a song that is sung.  It is a way of life and the principal on which this club stands.  I will cherish my memories of club glory under Klopp and the excitement and enjoyment this team has brought me.  The comeback against Barca; Origi's header to beat Everton; The 3 goal barrage to start a CL match against City; Allison with the game winner....there are too many memories to count.    I also have to say, this team has helped me bond with my little brother.  He is 10 years younger than I am, so growing up we weren't that close.  He moved to Seattle, WA and became a Sounders fan.  I turned him on to the Reds and their amazing Metal press.  We have watched matches together and we are both lifelong Reds fans as a result.  I have Klopp to thank for that.  You can be assured we will be making a pilgrimage one day to the hallowed grounds of Anfield.  I will weep at the eternal flame and place my note of remembrance at the shrine dedicated to the 97 people who lost their lives watching the team they loved.  I will watch my team play and I will be happy.    Thanks Jurgen.  YNWA JFT97

After watching Basketball all my life, I grew up in Los Angeles, watching and cheering on The Lakers all my life. Then, I moved to the bay and watched the Golden State Warriors grow to be champs. About six years ago, I grew out of Basketball; I became bored with the sport. I was always interested in soccer(football). I decided to jump in more and more and started watching PL games. My love grew, grew and grew for the game. I can remember two moments that cemented me in the sport. One was watching the Ajax vs Tottenham Champions League match with Lucas's hat-trick. The second was just Klopp. It's weird to obsess over a man, but Klopp is different. I could go on and on about Liverpool players, but Klopp. His energy, positivity, mentoring, and fun nature are stronger than the game to me. This is a massive loss for LFC, but I wish to thank this man for making me a fan of this club and the sport. Klopp, I wish you nothing but the best in life!

Man I really have no idea how to handle this. 10 years ago I needed something more in my life, I was flat, I had no aspirations, I was confused about what I would be in the future. I started watching more football, and found myself attached to Jurgen and his squad at Dortmund. I loved every second of each match I saw. I loved the atmosphere, I loved the spectacle, it let me feel emotions I didn't realize I had been repressing.   When Klopp announced he was leaving Dortmund, I was at a crossroads. I was finishing High School, and I didn't see a future for myself in further education. I saw my path very rapidly diverging from my peers. I had begun to find solace in watching Klopp lead his team, whether it was a good day or a bad day for me or the squad, it always served as an outlet that I couldn't find in normal life. Now that very personal ritual was being upended - just as my life was rapidly evolving.  Ten years before, I was in Paris with family on vacation on the night of the CL final in Istanbul. I fell asleep before the match kicked off. I wasn't even ten years old, an American kid who played Soccer but didn't have any love for professional clubs. When I woke up the next morning, I don't think I had ever seen my Dad so animated. He regaled our family with the story of the match - Milan had scored three, Liverpool had their backs against the wall. The comeback, the double save in extra time, Dudek's ('The Dude,' he affectionately called him) wobbly legs and becoming the hero in the shootout. My dad wasn't an LFC fan, he really wasn't a fan of any sports team. He loves tales of fighting back against impossible odds, he loves stories that help us understand our own humanity. It was the first time I saw sport as more than a game - in certain moments sport became an allegory for meaning itself.  When Jurgen announced he was coming to LFC that memory rushed back into my brain. I was certain then that I would support Jurgen, and LFC, and the journey they took together until they could go no further. Today, I learned the limits of where that journey could go. I struggle to think of where I go from here. For now I reflect on the memories, and of all the wonderful moments, and of all the tragedies, and of the songs, and of the goals.

saya masih belum memahami , kenapa klopp memutuskan untuk meninggalkan liverpool fc
I would argue that you can clearly see how much Klopp loves Liverpool FC. His honesty as well as the timing to notify everyone about his decision clearly spells this out. The fact that he noticed that he doesn't have the kind of energy to be able to continue managing the club in a way that would be beneficial for the team is indicative of that. To fans and the general public, his decision to quit managing seems to be sudden, but as we heard, he has been pondering this since at least November of last year.   I believe that this announcement came with the best interest of the club in mind. The fact that Klopp was going to be leaving at some stage in the future was inevitable, but this gives them time to plan for the continuity, for the next stage in the life of the club.  It seems to me that he doesn't see himself as the right man to continue bringing about the kind of results that he managed to bring about because he is no longer like what he used to be which was the catalyst for Liverpool's success.   The majority of the players are still young, and they will adapt well. I am sure that he will be working with them to prepare them for what is coming up next. If he told them at the end of the season, that would definitely be too much of a shock for them. Moreover, it would leave too much of a big hole to fill in too little time to fill it. It is a big hole to fill anyhow, but like I said earlier, at least they have time to think and plan and make a decision as to who can take over.   I would argue that Liverpool will need someone experienced but young enough, who has the necessary energy and drive to be able to implement specific changes that will facilitate certain growth without killing the new identity that Klopp managed to create and foster within the club, which is based on the kind of energetic style of play that made it into a successful club once again.  For this reason, I would argue that the next manager will need to have the necessary managerial and football nouse to be able to take them on to new heights without feeling the need to completely change Liverpool's style of play.
2 Words Xavi Alonso
Winning is difficult, the reality is that he is drained, he will go on and train elsewhere he is just tired of training Liverpool

Having grown up in London , I was on the wrong end of the stick for being born a German. Despite that I never hated the English. Jurgen has made a wise decision. He could see himself burning out and that carries all kinds of bad outcomes, both physical and mental. Sometimes the hardest decision is the one to walk away. Jurgen has made both a wise choice, and a correct one. Also by saying this now, he has done the honourable thing by his club, his players and the supporters. With this burden off his shoulders he can now manage Liverpool to the best of his ability, which is considerable, to say the least. It is easy to forget that the job of manager of an elite EPL team is a VERY TOUGH GIG. Add in the tradition and expectations that surround LFC, then you can double that pressure. I am sure that no one wants to see Jurgen collapse on the pitch and wind up in ICU at Liverpool Hospital. Or worse.  The constant intense pressure of todays elite sporting world is a multiple of what past managers had to deal with. You are not going to see a long term manager like a; Bill Shankly, Don Revie, Matt Busby or Brian Clough these days. The last of the "marathon men' was  Alex Ferguson at Manchester United. He lasted 17 years! Incredible. Jurgen's next chapter is just beginning.

I honestly can't describe my feelings at this moment. I feel empty from within by the very thought that jurgen won't be our gaffer from next season. It's just so heartbreaking. But at the same time having heard his reasons for this decision I can have nothing but more respect & adulation for him. If he thinks it's in the best interest of Liverpool football club for him to step down, then it sure is. Of everything he's done & said over the years as the gaffer, one thing comes to my mind, "it's not important how we feel when the manager comes in, but how we feel when he leaves". How right was he! The grief, the sadness, the desire to hold on to someone & not let them leave & so many feelings I'm experiencing now, I've never had in my life. I wonder how liverpudlians would've felt when shankly decided to step down. Jurgen was & will always be more than just a football manager for LFC. 9:30  "If you look at my career, this career is actually not possible, I would say, because where I'm coming from, ending up as the Manager of Liverpool FC is a fairy tale. It's a very difficult thing to plan, I would say impossible to plan, and difficult to reach. But it's only possible if you are very busy and 100,000% committed to everything you do. When you dedicate your whole life to it, that's what I did. I came here as a normal guy, I am still a normal guy. I just don't live a normal life for too long now. And I don't want to wait until I'm too old for having a normal life. I need at least to give it a try at one point to see how it is. Will I miss it?"   ç§ã®ã‚­ãƒ£ãƒªã‚¢ã‚’è¦‹ã¦ã‚‚ã‚‰ãˆã°ã‚ã‹ã‚‹ãŒã€ç§ã®å‡ºè‡ªã‹ã‚‰ãƒªãƒãƒ—ãƒ¼ãƒ«FCã®ãƒãƒãƒ¼ã‚¸ãƒ£ãƒ¼ã«ãªã‚‹ãªã‚“ã¦ã€æœ¬å½“ã«ãŠã¨ãè©±ã®ã‚ˆã†ãªã“ã¨ã§ã€è¨ˆç”»ã™ã‚‹ã“ã¨ã¯ä¸å¯èƒ½ã§ã€åˆ°é”ã™ã‚‹ã®ã‚‚é›£ã—ã„ã€‚ã—ã‹ã—ã€ãã‚Œã¯ã‚ãªãŸãŒéå¸¸ã«å¿™ã—ãã€ã‚„ã‚‹ã“ã¨å…¨ã¦ã«100,000ï¼…ã‚³ãƒŸãƒƒãƒˆã—ã¦ã€ä¸€ç”Ÿã‚’æ§ã’ã‚‹æ™‚ã«ã®ã¿å¯èƒ½ã ã€‚ãã‚ŒãŒç§ãŒã‚„ã£ã¦ããŸã“ã¨ã ã€‚ç§ã¯æœ€åˆã®æ—¥ã‹ã‚‰ã€æ™®é€šã®ç”·ã¨ã—ã¦ã“ã“ã«æ¥ãŸã€‚ç§ã¯ã¾ã æ™®é€šã®ç”·ã ã€‚ãŸã ã€é•·ã„é–“ã€æ™®é€šã®äººç”Ÿã‚’é€ã£ã¦ã„ãªã„ã ã‘ã ã€‚ãã—ã¦ã€è‡ªåˆ†ãŒå¹´ã‚’å–ã‚Šã™ãã¦æ™®é€šã®äººç”Ÿã‚’é€ã‚Œãªããªã‚‹ã®ã‚’å¾…ã¡ãŸããªã„ã€‚å°‘ãªãã¨ã‚‚ã€ã©ã†ãªã‚‹ã‹è©¦ã—ã¦ã¿ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚‹ã€‚ãã‚Œã‚’é€ƒã—ãŸã“ã¨ã¯ãªã„ãŒã€è©¦ã—ã¦ã¿ã‚‹å¿…è¦ãŒã‚ã‚‹ã€‚

I am a little bit younger than Klopp so I've been around LFC for a while. The Klopp era is the greatest era of this football club since King Kenny's time at the club. We loved Rafa and were gutted when he left, we had an odd relationship with Brendan but he almost won us the title so when he left he didn't know if things would get better or worse but life went on. Klopp came in and built us back up and the club will carry on as it has since the 19th century. It is the end of an era and it is sad and it is scary because we don't know what lies ahead. It could be a continuation and and expansion on what Klopp has given us or we could stumble and struggle to find the right man to replace him but we won't do it alone. We will still have so many of these players who are leaders who understand how to continue this culture and we, as fans, have to keep supporting. YNWA

everton fan here, even tho we are arch enemies, i love jurgen and i hate to see him go after such a great career with liverpool. he will be missed by not only liverpool, but everyone.
The first Liverpool manager I remember might be Brendan Rodgers. But the first man who made me realize what a manager is was Mr. Jurgen Klopp. Those antiques, fist pumps at the away end, Klopp hugs, press, and infamous excuses have all been a treat. As Carra said, "This news was always going to be a body blow to the club whenever it came. I just thought it would be another few years away."  From delivering the 1st premier league trophy in 30 years to winning our 6th UCL title, from becoming champions of the world to winning every possible trophy in English football, having Jurgen lead us was a boon. He has been a serial winner. Truthfully, I had expected him to at least outlive his current contract. My heart was in smithereens when the news was broken this afternoon. Like I had been punched in my stomach.   Filling in his boots will be a very difficult job for whoever is going to replace him. Still, I would sincerely like to thank Jurgen for the fondest footballing memories I have.  For the last few times before he's gone " I'm so glad that Jurgen is a Red"  YNWA, Jurgen.

O Leader! My Leader! ğŸ«¡ğŸ«¡ğŸ«¡
It is with a mixture of admiration and melancholy that I pen this to bid farewell to a remarkable era in Liverpool Football Club's history. The news of Jurgen Klopp's departure at the end of the season has undoubtedly stirred emotions among the vast family of Liverpool supporters worldwide.  Jurgen, your tenure at Anfield has been nothing short of extraordinary. From the moment you arrived, you brought a renewed sense of hope, passion, and an unwavering commitment to excellence. Your infectious enthusiasm, touchline antics, and, most importantly, your undeniable impact on the team have left an indelible mark on the hearts of every Liverpool fan. Under your guidance, we witnessed incredible triumphs, unforgettable moments, and a style of football that captured the imagination of the entire footballing world. The Premier League title, and the Champions League glory â€“ these are just a few chapters of the story you've written with Liverpool. Your legacy is one of unity, resilience, and a relentless pursuit of greatness.  To the Liverpool supporters, you have been the backbone of this journey. Your unwavering support through thick and thin has been the driving force behind the team's success. The songs, the banners, the sea of red â€“ you created an atmosphere that turned Anfield into a fortress and made Liverpool more than just a football club, but a global family. As Jurgen Klopp bids farewell to Anfield, let us collectively express our deepest gratitude for the joy, pride, and camaraderie he has brought to our lives. Jurgen, you are not just leaving a football club; you are leaving an everlasting legacy etched in the hearts of millions.  To the supporters, as we navigate through this moment of transition, let us continue to stand united, supporting the team through the highs and lows that undoubtedly lie ahead. The spirit of Liverpool endures, and the bond forged during Klopp's tenure will remain unbreakable. Wishing Jurgen Klopp all the success in his future endeavors, and may the Liverpool family continue to thrive, building upon the foundation of passion, unity, and love for the beautiful game.  You'll Never Walk Alone.

I really like his decision to tell everybody the news half a year before season ends. For me it's just another proof of his love and care for the club, although I had no doubt about it anyway. I totally understand and accept his decision. I feel like I know what it's like too because I've been in kinda similar situation in life, just with much less responsibility in it, still it was quite significant for me and the people around me. It felt weird as well to think 'well i can still do it now and i really like doing it, but I know it's the right time to leave in [three] months'. It's kinda like eating a piece of cake that your friend cooked for you, you know. 'I don't want to eat the whole cake but not beacuse i don't like it. It's just beacuse I like it THE MOST when I eat just one or two pieces'. I find his decision and the explanation to be of so high quality that it even annoys me that he has to explain it to people for so many times in different ways for 25 minutes. But I think I understand why he does it. He just wants to make sure that every single person gets it, especially those who never been in such situations in life.

I was never a football fan until point in 2015 I started a new job and everyone that I worked with was always talking about the Premier League in which I did not know what this was.   To fit in (as you do) I asked around and researched the clubs in the prem and at the time everyone I spoke to said Liverpool was an underdog team which  had me hooked.   I started watching highlights and replays of Liverpool games and at the time Brendan Rogers got sacked and Jurgen Klopp came in and the rest is history!  I have had the biggest highs and lows as a Liverpool supporter (in Australia) and this was all down to Jurgen.   I am absolutely gutted as this has been my manager for my whole supporter lifespan but I completely understand Jurgen's position and I wish him and his family all the best!  Thank you!
